Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, my mom bustling around, reminding me for the third time that I needed to be ready for the family holiday dinner in an hour. My little sister was already dressed, excitedly talking about the games we’d play after dinner. I knew how much these family gatherings meant to everyone, especially since we didn’t get together often. Just as I was about to head upstairs to change, my phone buzzed. It was a message from my friend, Sam: “Hey, can you talk? I’ve had the worst day. Everything just feels pointless right now.” I stared at the screen, feeling a knot tighten in my stomach. Sam rarely reached out like this, and I knew he needed someone to listen. But I could already hear my mom calling my name, asking if I was getting ready. I felt torn—my family expected me to be present and cheerful, but Sam was counting on me to be there for him. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I didn’t know how I could possibly be what everyone needed at the same time.
